title: Can I put a lien on someone's assets to ensure payment of debt?
question: I am a California resident. An associates wants me to loan him 200k. The loan will be in a form of a line of credit. Everything will be in writing. The borrower has several pieces of real estate with equity on it. I would like to know is there a way for me to put a lien on his real estate property for the loan amount, register the lien with the county recorder so as to ensure that in case the debt is not paid, I can have access to his equity and get my money. I am very much interested in the process of putting the lien and having it be recorded. Thanks in advance.
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Credit,Debt,Lien,Bankruptcy and debt,Real estate and bankruptcy,Real estate
answers: Not a lien, but rather a deed of trust. You need both a written promissory note and a deed of trust. Once notarized, record the deed of trust in the Los Angeles County Recorder's Office.

It's called a deed of trust, not a lien, and it means that your loan is secured by the real property. Equity or not, you need to make sure that there aren't other debts or judgments against this potential borrower, which title reports on the properties will show. .

You also need to make sure that you have a properly drafted promissory note with appropriate interest and enforcement provisions. There's too much money at stake here not to hire a lawyer, so don't do this yourself, see a real estate lawyer for help.

Is your associate willing to grant you a lien on his property? If so, then you can have an attorney prepare a note and deed of trust to make sure that you have a valid lien on his property. Also, make sure that the attorney has a title search performed. You do not want to get the lien only to find out that there is no equity in the property or that you are severely undersecured. You also want to discuss with your associate who will pay the closing costs.

[I am a Virginia-licensed attorney. This communication is intended as general information and not specific legal advice, and this communication does not create an attorney-client relationship.]

A lien can be voluntarily created to tie up real estate using a deed of trust or a mortgage.

I would recommend obtaining professional help to prepare these documents.

Good luck!
